text: What do you think, is there any benefit from an API that connects different platforms? E.g. I have a Betfair marketId and would like to load statistics from Sportradar for this market. Or I have a match from 7msport and would like to load the odds from oddsportal? For that I need a map: {BetfairMarketId: SportradarMatchId}. Would you use an API that provides such connections or is it useless?

elements.text: What do you think, is there any benefit from an API that connects different platforms? E.g. I have a Betfair marketId and would like to load statistics from Sportradar for this market. Or I have a match from 7msport and would like to load the odds from oddsportal? For that I need a map: {BetfairMarketId: SportradarMatchId}. Would you use an API that provides such connections or is it useless?

text: The name mapping has a significant manual component. Are you talking about an existing API?

text: And each event has a number of markets, so you are actually mapping a number of markets (prices) to an event (stats)

text: A smal API is running allready that  links Bong88 soccer matches to Sportradar

text: No manual part included.

elements.text: No manual part included.

text: How do you map the matches?

elements.text: How do you map the matches?

text: At one point on Bong88 you get information about sportradar. I use this information to load and return the match. With other providers, for example, I load all matches in a league from both providers. Then I compare which names play most often at the same time (with a few minutes of tolerance) and the most frequent hit is then: ProviderA_HomeTeamName = ProviderB_HomerTeamName. With this information I can clearly link all matches in the season.

elements.text: At one point on Bong88 you get information about sportradar. I use this information to load and return the match. With other providers, for example, I load all matches in a league from both providers. Then I compare which names play most often at the same time (with a few minutes of tolerance) and the most frequent hit is then: ProviderA_HomeTeamName = ProviderB_HomerTeamName. With this information I can clearly link all matches in the season.

text: Hey chaps, techy question, currently I use SQL Server as my database software (locally). I am starting some work that will basically give me a chance to remodel all my database work going forward. I run everything locally atm but there is scope for this side project to be run on AWS / cloud and my stuff also down the line. Am I right in thinking there is high license fees for SQL server on AWS? If so what opensource/free SQL databases would people recommend

elements.text: Hey chaps, techy question, currently I use SQL Server as my database software (locally). I am starting some work that will basically give me a chance to remodel all my database work going forward. I run everything locally atm but there is scope for this side project to be run on AWS / cloud and my stuff also down the line. Am I right in thinking there is high license fees for SQL server on AWS? If so what opensource/free SQL databases would people recommend

text: I use SQL Server development version which is free. SQL licenses are expensive but if you’re the only user there’s no reason to buy one. Been using the developer version for years with no problems. If you’re running windows server on AWS I can’t see any problems.

elements.text: I use SQL Server development version which is free. SQL licenses are expensive but if you’re the only user there’s no reason to buy one. Been using the developer version for years with no problems. If you’re running windows server on AWS I can’t see any problems.

text:
Yeah just be sensible:

• Use a VPN or proxy
• Don’t take the piss with your request frequency
• Ideally use something like Selenium so it looks like you are a proper browser (if you are making a request to the front end rather than back end)
